claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces a strong local type I interferon response in tumors.

evidence.quote: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: The report summarizes normalized scores, but does not specify timing, assay details, or variability across models in this excerpt.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens tumor antigen presentation, including an expanded MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: The intervention increases PD-L1 pathway activity in tumor tissue, supporting combination with checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

claims.caveat: An increase in PD-L1 expression can have multiple biological interpretations, and the excerpt does not provide effect sizes across all tumor models.

claims.claim: Combination therapy improves tumor control in mice and is consistent with improved survival in a retrospective vaccinated human subgroup receiving ICI.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely, and vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.

claims.claim: The sensitization benefit depends on type I interferon signaling, because IFNAR1 blockade eliminates the effect.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: These results are described at a summary level here, and the excerpt does not specify which tumor models or endpoints were used for the IFNAR1 perturbation.
